title: Judicial notice of pleadings in related case. Can assertions made by a party (i.e. motion) in a related case be noticed?
question: I am suing a vendor company and its officers for breach of contract and fraud (the company is small family owned - so owner = officer). I filed in state court. Vendor company filed for bankruptcy (not officers). The vendor's petition for federal bankruptcy, motion to extend stay to officer and declaration in support (?) made statements about acknowledgement of debts to creditors and financial standing. Motion to extend stay was rejected by bankruptcy court. Can I know use the company's petition, motion statements and declaration against the officers in state court? Do I need judicial notice?
answers: I agree with attorney Chen's solid advice. I add that although the truth of hearsay statements cannot generally be judicially noticed, there is an argument that a "judicial admission" — an admission made in a judicial pleading — is not subject to a hearsay objection. The concept of hearsay is complicated (it confounds many law students) and what constitutes an "admission" is not always self-evident. Accordingly, I do not attempt to explain either here and mention them only to alert you. You should consider talking to a lawyer as it sounds like you have some complicated legal matters to deal with. Good luck.

First of all, you do need to request that the court take judicial notice. It is not automatic, and you can't just attach documents from the bankruptcy case to your state court motion.

https://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/judicial-notice-in-california?ref=kb_serp_title_1

Secondly, you will probably not likely be able to have the court take judicial notice of the truth of statements made in the bankruptcy court. Judicial notice may be taken of the records of any federal or state court; however, not all matters contained in court records (e.g., pleadings, affidavits, etc.) are indisputably true. While the existence of any document in a court file may be judicially noticed, the truth of matters asserted in such documents is not necessarily subject to judicial notice. (Sosinsky v. Grant (1992) 6 Cal.App.4th 1548, 1564–1569; Evid. Code 452(d).)

The court may not take judicial notice of the truth of hearsay statements in decisions and court files and may not take notice of allegations in declarations. (Kilroy v. State of California 119 Cal. App. 4th 140, 145 [June 2004] citing Lockley v. Law Office of Cantrell, Green, Pekich, Cruz & McCort (2001) 91 Cal. App. 4th 875,882.)

https://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/tips-regarding-requesting-judicial-notice-in-california?ref=kb_serp_title_2
